paragraphs.text: What freedom of speech?
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: The photos of 40 of the world's government leaders marching arm-in-arm along a Paris boulevard on Sunday with the president of the United States not among them was a provocative image that has fomented much debate
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The march was, of course, in direct response to the murderous attacks on workers at the French satirical magazine Charlie Hebdo by a pair of brothers named Kouachi, and on shoppers at a Paris kosher supermarket by one of the brothers' comrades
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The debate has been about whether President Obama should have been at the march
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The march was billed as a defense of freedom of speech in the West
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: yet
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it hardly could have been held in a less free speech-friendly Western environment
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the debate over Obama's absence misses the point
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In the post-World War II era, French governments have adopted a policy advanced upon them nearly 100 years ago by Woodrow Wilson
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: He pioneered the modern idea that countries' constitutions don't limit governments; they unleash them
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Thus
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: even though the French Constitution guarantees freedom of speech, French governments treat speech as a gift from the government, not as a natural right of all persons
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: as our Constitution does
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The French government has prohibited speech it considers to be hateful and even made it criminal
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: When the predecessor magazine to Charlie Hebdo once mocked the death of Charles de Gaulle, the French government shut it down -- permanently
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The theory of anti-hate speech laws is that hate speech often leads to violence, and violence demands police and thus the expenditure of public resources, and so the government can make it illegal to spout hatred in order to conserve its resources
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: This attitude presumes, as Wilson did when he prosecuted folks for publicly singing German songs during World War I, that the government is the origin of free speech and can lawfully limit the speech it hates and fears
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It also presumes that all ideas are equal, and none is worthy of hatred
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: When the massacres occurred last week in Paris, all three of the murderers knew that the police would be unarmed and so would be their victims
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It was as if they were shooting fish in a barrel
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Why is that?
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: The answer lies in the same mentality that believes it can eradicate hate by regulating speech
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: That mentality demands that government have a monopoly on violence, even violence against evil
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: So, to those who embrace this dreadful theory, the great loss in Paris last week was not human life, which is a gift from God
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: it was free speech, which is a gift from the state
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Hence the French government, which seems not to care about innocent life, instead of addressing these massacres as crimes against innocent people, proclaimed the massacres crimes against the freedom of speech
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Would the French government have reacted similarly if the murderers had killed workers at an ammunition factory, instead of at a satirical magazine?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: how hypocritical was it of the French government to claim it defends free speech!
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In France, you can go to jail if you publicly express hatred for a group whose members may be defined generally by characteristics of birth, such as gender, age, race, place of origin or religion
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: You can also go to jail for using speech to defy the government
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: This past weekend, millions of folks in France wore buttons and headbands that proclaimed in French:"I am Charlie Hebdo."
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Those whose buttons proclaimed"I am not Charlie Hebdo" were asked by the police to remove them
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Those who wore buttons that proclaimed, either satirically or hatefully,"I am Kouachi" were arrested
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Arrested for speech at a march in support of free speech?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Yes
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: What's going on here?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: What's going on in France, and what might be the future in America, is the government defending the speech with which it agrees and punishing the speech with which it disagrees
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: What's going on is the assault by some in radical Islam not on speech, but on vulnerable innocents in their everyday lives in order to intimidate their governments
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: What's going on is the deployment of 90,000 French troops to catch and kill three murderers
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: because the government does not trust the local police to use guns to keep the streets safe or private persons to use guns to defend their own lives
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Why do some in radical Islam kill innocents in the West in order to affect the policies of Western governments?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Might it be because the fruitless Western invasion of Iraq killed 650,000 persons, most of whom were innocent civilians?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Might it be because that invasion brought al-Qaida to the region and spawned ISIS?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Might it be because Obama has killed more innocent civilians in the Middle East with his drones than were killed by the planes in the U.S  on 9/11?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Might it be because our spies are listening to us, rather than to those who pose real dangers?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: What does all this have to do with freedom of speech?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Nothing -- unless you believe the French government
paragraphs.label: assumption
